body: (Feel free to reopen it if it's unclear)

@philipperemy thank you. I got it running by adjusting `Dense(1)` in the following lines:
```
    else:
        # regression
        x = Dense(1)(x)
        x = Activation('linear', name='output_dense')(x)
```

@joelrich ok that will work in all the cases. You have to keep in mind that it won't be optimal if you have a time-dependency in what you predict.

```
 Dense(4)(x) => will predict 4 independent values at the same time.
It's like predicting P(X1, X2, X3, X4 | Z).
```

If you have a sequence, it's usually better to model and consider this likelihood:
```
P(X1 | Z)
+ P(X2 | X1, Z)
+ P(X3 | X1, X2, Z)
+ P(X4 | X1, X2, X3, Z)
For this I guess a TimeDistributed(Dense()) layer should work.
```

https://machinelearningmastery.com/timedistributed-layer-for-long-short-term-memory-networks-in-python/
@philipperemy currently, I am predicting independent values. Thanks for the advice anyway (might be relevant later on).

Actually I'm not really sure with TimeDistributed. Please do your own research :)

Welcome!
@philipperemy I can't decide whether I'm being really dense or this is a nomenclature issue (or both). If I set regression=True and return_sequences=True, isn't this many to many regression?

Regression=True => regression task with output = 1
Regression=False => classification task

regression=True and return_sequences=True won't give you a many to many regression.

Many to many is actually not handled properly in the compile_tcn code. 

https://github.com/philipperemy/keras-tcn/blob/6d71e1946910748a4fb99ce53b29d312ddfb82b2/tcn/tcn.py#L250

You have to update manually this line.

I'd like to work on it but I'm a bit busy at the moment...

This is why I'm suggesting return_sequences=True corresponds to what some people call many to many:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43034960/many-to-one-and-many-to-many-lstm-examples-in-keras

That is, the "many" refers to multiple time steps, rather than multiple outputs.
@swilson314 yes what you're saying totally makes sense. I'll try to find some time soon to implement this.
@philipperemy Haha, my point is I think many to many is already implemented. I'm putting together an example to verify.
